text: This comment was a reply to someone else but I'll post this on google+ too because it's an interesting topic:  I agree with you about the "cultured" idea (calling someone uncultured when they don't like some particular thing). It's sort of an arbitrary way of putting yourself above people if you ask me. It's like saying my favorite flavor of ice cream is x, therefore I'm better. I guess it's tempting for people to do this because then all they have to do is eat some food and they're automatically cool or something :) Anyway I don't think we should be bound to doing things that people consider "cool," but be confident in our own judgment. If I feel like having soda, I'll still have soda, even if people will find an arbitrary problem with me not drinking, say, wine instead. But from my perspective, I would just be drinking what I felt like drinking, and wouldn't feel a need to change just because someone would claim, with unjustified certainty, that there's something wrong with that. And in order to make such a claim look semi-plausible, they would probably hide behind a word like "uncultured," because the word sounds sophisticated :)

text: It seems to me we've still not mastered the art of making a realistic, charming 3D character. Paddington does not look like he fits in with the environs, not only of Paddington station and England, but in this world. Perhaps even this universe.
